user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_calc_hash:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
digest_calc_hash (struct DigestAlgorithm *da, uint8_t *digest)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->uninitialised);
  mhd_assert (da->algo_selected);
  mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH
    MHD_MD5_finish (&da->ctx.md5_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#else  /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_MD5_finish_reset (&da->ctx.md5_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#endif /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH
    MHD_SHA256_finish (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#else  /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_SHA256_finish_reset (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#endif /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == da->algo)
  {
    MHD_SHA512_256_finish (&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  mhd_assert (0);   /* Should not happen */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  da->hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function digest_calc_hash:
struct DigestAlgorithm
{
  /**
   * A context for the digest algorithm, already initialized to be
   * useful for @e init, @e update and @e digest.
   */
  union DigestCtx ctx;

  /**
   * The hash calculation algorithm.
   */
  enum MHD_DigestBaseAlgo algo;

  /**
   * Buffer for hex-print of the final digest.
   */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  bool uninitialised; /**< The structure has been not set-up */
  bool algo_selected; /**< The algorithm has been selected */
  bool ready_for_hashing; /**< The structure is ready to hash data */
  bool hashing; /**< Some data has been hashed, but the digest has not finalised yet */
#endif /* _DEBUG */
}
...
#define MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT 1
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I have reported all code locations in the function that use pointer types (function parameters and addresses taken of ctx fields) which should be reviewed for Rule 8.13 (whether the pointed-to types could be const-qualified). Other fragments do not need investigation for this rule: the mhd_assert() checks reference boolean fields (no pointers); the #ifdef / #else blocks and macros are preprocessor control flow (no pointer qualification issue by themselves); assignments to debug flags (e.g. da->ready_for_hashing = true/false; da->hashing = false) are modifications of the object passed via 'da' and thus the pointer cannot be to const; the final mhd_assert(0) and the enum/flag accesses do not introduce additional pointer parameters that could/should be const-qualified. Therefore the listed fragments cover all places in the provided code where non-const pointers are passed or taken and should be inspected for possible const qualification.
